moves.1. e4 c6: Caro-Kann Defence. This game is the first time - and surprisingly the only time to date - I have encountered it in actual play.
moves.3... Bf5 4. Nc3 e6 5. g4: The beginning of an aggressive continuation, the bayonette attack.
moves.5... Bg6 6. Nge2: The best deployment for the knight in this variation.
moves.6... Ne7: Black adopts a quiet formation originating with Karpov, avoiding the wild tactics that can otherwise occur.
moves.7. Nf4 Nd7 8. h4 h6 9. Nxg6 Nxg6 10. h5: In the last few moves white has gained some space, weakened some light squares on black's king's side, and removed the light-squared bishop which was protecting them.
moves.11. Ne2: Now white regroups in the centre, awaiting black's French-style counter-attack.
moves.11... c5 12. c3 Nc6 13. f4 cxd4 14. cxd4: A pawn weakness for white, which black will try to exploit.
moves.14... Qb6 15. a3: Preventing Bb4 , which would disrupt white's support for his weak pawn.
moves.15... Be7: Black's bishop, though technically "good", no longer has many options.
moves.16. Bg2: White's king's side formation may look unusual, but the plan is to exert pressure on black's pawn centre. (This eventually happens, though not until the endgame.)
moves.16... O-O-O 17. b3: To allow the development of the other bishop, though this move allows black to create a few problems.
moves.17... Kb8 18. Qd3: Still protecting the two pawns, but now also pressuring the weakened light squares f5 and g6.
moves.18... Rdc8 19. Be3: Extra protection for d4, though this does not last long.
moves.19... Na5 20. b4: Allowing black a knight outpost on f4. This was a conscious decision, banking on being able to generate more important play on the other side of the board.
moves.20... Nc4 21. Bc1: Preserving the bishop and shackling the black knight.
moves.21... Qc7 22. f5: Now it is once again white's turn to go on the attack.
moves.22... Ndb6 23. O-O: Not the most comfortable castled position, but at least the rooks are nearly connected.
moves.23... Rcf8: This gives white a tactical target.
moves.24. Nf4: threatening forks on both e6 and g6 after a pawn exchange.
moves.24... Qd7 25. Re1: A sidestep to prevent black's rook escaping from the coming fork with Rxf1 .
moves.25... Bg5: This will lead to an exchange of dark squared bishops, which should not ultimately be to black's advantage. Better would have been to admit Rcf8 was a mistake and move it away again.
moves.27... Bxc1 28. Rexc1 Rhg8 29. Nxf8 Rxf8: Seizing the f-file for the rooks, as black can keep the c-file blocked.
moves.34. Kf2: Putting the question to the intruding knight.
moves.34... Nc4: Black obviously judges that this knight is stronger than the bishop - which might appear logical, but that is not how things will work out.
moves.35. Re8: The big question for me at this point was to stop black큦 queen coming down the c-file and possibly getting a perpetual (or worse). I thought this plan was the best way of tying her down.
moves.35... Nxa3 36. Qxe6 Qxe6: Qc6 would have allowed the pleasing tactic 37 Qd6  Qxd6, 38 ed!
moves.37. Rxe6 Nc2 38. Bxd5: The bishop joins the action at last.
moves.39... a5: Black's remaing trump is of course this pawn.
moves.40. Rg6: White insists on going for the g7 pawn, attacking b7 and securing a winning breakthrough for an eventual pawn ending.
moves.42. Bxc6: Disconnecting black큦 passed pawns. It might look as if the white rook is cut off from the a-pawn, but in fact it will reach it in time.
moves.42... bxc6 43. Ke3: Getting out of the rook큦 way, while also threatening to enter the a-pawn큦 square.
moves.43... a3 44. Rf7 Nb6: A last attempt to make trouble with the knight from d5.
moves.45. Kd3: Getting the king off the a7-g1 diagonal in the event of a pawn race after g5.
moves.45... a2 46. Rf1 Nd5 47. Ra1 Kc7: Hoping for 48 Rxa2? Nb4! (In fact this would probably still have lost - the knight is too far away from the king´s side pawns.)
moves.48. Kd2: 1-0. Black resigns because of the breakthrough 49 g5!, where neither king nor knight can catch the h-pawn.
